turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Are you seeing somebody else, Nathan? I just have to know.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Of course not.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: It would just be helpful to know.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Because, you know, you seem so distant. And you work late every night. And we hardly ever have sex, and when we do, it's... I don't know. It feels different.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: I'm just preoccupied.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Do you like my new look?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Yeah. It's nice. It's really good.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I'm trying, you know.  I'm trying to be what you want. I want to be what you want, Nathan. All I want is to be what you want.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Shh. It's okay.  It's okay, Lila. You're what I want. You know that. You're exactly what I want.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Sure. Of course.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Because I'm really trying, you know. Rosie says maybe only another two years of the elctrolysis.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: That's great.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I've signed up for a ballet class. And look at my nails! A real girl!

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: That's great. It's a great color for you.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Oh, Nathan, let's have a baby!

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Oh!  I didn't see you there, sneaky boy!  You're like a boy sneaking in...

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: ...the back door of a movie theater. Yes, indeed.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: You remember that from my book? I'm touched!  What's wrong?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Nothing. Hard day. Gonna have a drink.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I'll make it.  I'm so happy, Nathan! Everything's going to be so great! Scotch on the rocks, right?  Just kidding. I know what you drink, mister. I know what you drink.  Voila!

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: How's work?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Cruddy, okay? Are you satisfied?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: No. I don't want your work to be cruddy.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: My assistant quit today. Okay? He was highly valuable to the project.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Oh, baby. I'm sorry. Can't you hire somebody else?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: I guess.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Hey! I could come work for you! I know I haven't been all that supportive of this project, but I've come around.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Have you?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Oh yes, baby! I think that this is a wonderful project you're doing, taking this poor unfortunate, uncivilized creature and turning him into a human being! What a wonderful wonderful compassionate man you are!

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Yes! And I want to help. You won't have to pay me, and I was thinking of giving up that crazy nature writing anyway.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: How come?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Who needs it? I have you and I have being a woman and I have thinking about womanly things! I love being a woman because...

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Such as what womanly things?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Such as my man and how to please him!  Such as making wonderful dinners for my man!  Such as looking pretty for my man!  And I'm writing an article on quilting for the Ladies Home Journal!

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I had sold my fucking soul.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: I let her sell her soul. I stood by as she did it. It's inexcusable.  At the time though I thought it might help.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Bravo to you, Puff!

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: That was wonderful!

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: I think he's ready.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Oh boy!

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: You just have to control it. We're not apes.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Thank you very much for that.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Puff, I'm proud of you! You did remarkably well under difficult circumstances.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Absolutely!

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: I'm going to go down and check on Puff. See how he's holding up.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Should I come with?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Nah. You just relax. How's the book?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Ummm. It's good.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: You were gone a long time.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Yeah. Puff and I got into a big, philosophical discussion. He's really quite well read, considering he's only been literate for a month now. He's going to make us famous, Lila.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: So he's doing okay?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Seemed fine. Quiet evening enjoying his new digs.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: That's funny because, you know, I just went and picked him up at some flophouse on the lower eastside. He called here when he ran out of his "mad" money after spending an entire evening drinking, watching strippers, and fucking a whore!  Oh, and what did you do tonight, honey?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Shit.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: And what did you do tonight, honey?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: I've fallen in love with somebody else, Lila.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: And what did you do tonight, honey?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: I fucked her! Okay? I fucked her. I'm sorry. But that's what the hell I did.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Do you know what I gave up to be with you?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: I gave up my soul, my beliefs. I gave up my body hair!

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Yeah, well, I'm sorry. The human heart is a strange thing.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: How the hell would you know anything about the human heart?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Lila...

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Shut up! Yeah, this is Lila, cunt. And don't let the hirsutism fool you. I know more about being a woman, and more about the black hearts of men than you, in your pretty little powdered, bullshit fantasy world, can ever imagine. I know the darkness and cruelty of nature, sweetie pie.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Lila, you don't intend to hurt us, do you?

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Eat shit, thumbtack dick!  Thank you, Frank. You're the best.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Aha! Finally. I've covered almost the entire seaboard and parts of eastern Ohio.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Ugnh.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Look at you two. You both disgust me.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Oook. Oook.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Shut up!  I gave you... life. I created you in my image, Puff. I took you from this primordial ooze and brought you into the world of culture and art and manners. And this is how you repay me? By heading back to the ooze first chance you get? I should leave you here with Lila the ape woman. It would serve you right, you ungrateful piece of crap. But I'm not going to. You're too valuable to me. Totally selfish of me. You serve my purpose. But if you had any smarts you would realize that I serve your purpose as well. Life is so much more delightful when lived in a silk suit.

turns.speaker: LILA
turns.text: Ooka.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Don't worry, Lila. You can stay. I don't have any interest in you anymore.  C'mon, monkey boy.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: Good-eve-n-ing-lay-dees-and-gent- elmen.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Bravo, Puff! Bravo!

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: Oh boy!

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Now, Puff, we're leaving on the electronic collar. I don't think we'll need to shock you, but just in case.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: Okay. That's fair.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: This is great, Puff. You're doing fine.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: I'm loving this. It's such a treat to be out and about. What a wonderful invention a city is. The immense buildings of glass and steel glinting in the afternoon sun, the smartly dressed women in their best summer frocks, the colorful street vendors.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: I don't think this aversion therapy is really necessary, doctor. I understand the problem.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Humor me, Puff. It's essential that I am able to trust you to function independently in the world.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: I bow to your expertise in these matters.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Lila?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Excellent work, Puff. Extra desert tonight.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: Yahoo!

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Tomorrow, the acid test.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: Did I? I tried so hard! I really concentrated! Oh, I'm so happy!

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: And because you did so well, we have a little surprise for you.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: Extra dessert?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Even better.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Free to come and go as you please. There's some "mad money" in the night table drawer.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: It's wonderful! Do you think I'm ready? Do you really?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: I trust that you'll make good, mature decisions. I trust that you'll do the proper thing.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: Oh, I will!  Your very trust has instilled an enormous sense of responsibility in me. I don't want to disappoint you.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Good. Remember, when in doubt: Don't ever do what you really want to do.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: Got it.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Puff, why don't you say a few words to the assemblage.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: It would be my pleasure, doctor.  Distinguished gentlemen and ladies of the psychological community, I stand before you today, a living testament to the amazing skill of Dr. Nathan Bronfman. To say that he took me from crayons to perfume would be a vast understatement. Dr. Bronfman took me from playing with my own feces, then to crayons, and then to an appreciation of the complex works of Franz Kline, Joseph Beuys, and Marcel Duchamp. From compulsive masturbation to...

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: Thanks to you, Nate.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Thanks to you, Buddy. And your diligence and intelligence and perseverance.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: And of course to you, my sweet, for your... moral support.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: here, here.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: Interesting.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Now, my diminutive friend, what can I do for you?

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: Ugnh.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Oh please, is that as articulate as you can be after all the time I spent teaching you? We've discussed Wittgenstein, for Christ's sake. Not that you ever had anything very original or challenging to say on the subject.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: Unn.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Down from the tree. Both of you. Keep your hands where I can see them. Don't want you pulling any weapons out of your fur.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Puff, put the gun down.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: Ounpoo. Ungh.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Let's be reasonable human beings here. We're all reasonable human beings, aren't we?

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: Unka unka unka unka unka.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Look, why don't you and Lila stay here and have your natural life. I'll just go on my way. You'll never see me again.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: I have to talk. Is that okay?

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: You did create me in your image, Nathan. Before you I was a simple, happy, complete being, in harmony with the world around me. After you I became duplicitous, cynical, angry, anal, totally out of touch with my surroundings. In a word, Nathan, I became you. Lila has reintroduced me to myself. And, incidentally, what I'm about to do, kill you, is something that would never have occurred to me to do as a creature of the Earth. Before when I killed, it was for food or in self-defense. Now I will kill for revenge. Revenge is an abstract concept, Nathan. And I learned abstract thinking from you.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: So anyway, that's the nightmare I've been having lately.

turns.speaker: WENDALL
turns.text: Do you suppose it has anything to do with Lila's unusually hairy body?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: No, why?

turns.speaker: WENDALL
turns.text: Well, it seems that since Lila broached the subject of children, you've been on edge and I know you have an issue with the, uh, body hair.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Oh, I see. Yes, that's something to think about. That's very good. That's what you get the big bucks, right? Ha ha.

turns.speaker: WENDALL
turns.text: I just think it might be important to explore your feelings for Lila.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: I love Lila. I mean, she's a wonderful person. And... she loves me! That's no small potatoes. I mean she really loves me. She's sacrificed so much to be in this relationship with me. And she's a good person. A truly good person. How rare is that in this world, eh? And how could I stop loving somebody because of a little physical imperfection, if it can even be called that. I mean, God knows I'm not perfect! What about my eyesight? It's lousy, that's what! Lila's not going to leave me because of my eyesight. What about my penis?

turns.speaker: WENDALL
turns.text: And how do you feel about Gabrielle?

turns.speaker: OLDER WOMAN
turns.text: Wait!

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: OLDER WOMAN
turns.text: I saw you on C-Span. I've been looking for you for thirty years. Then there you were, such a beautiful, beautiful grown man.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: Mother?

turns.speaker: OLDER WOMAN
turns.text: Yes... Derek.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: It's a pleasure to meet you, mother. But I'm an ape like dad was...  And I have to go back into the woods now... forever.

turns.speaker: OLDER WOMAN
turns.text: Yes, I suppose so. I suppose I knew that was going to be what you would say. It's good to see you again though.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: OLDER WOMAN
turns.text: I'm in the book, if you ever want to drop me a line or something.

turns.speaker: PUFF
turns.text: I'm an ape, mom. I'm an ape. And apes don't drop lines.

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: Boys just passing through?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yep.

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: Pittsburgh?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Mm hmm.

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: Comin' in or goin' out?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Goin' in. We got a sales convention. Gotta be there tomorrow.

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: What do you guys sell?

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: Thanks. Sure is a hot day for driving. Late afternoon is better. You guys have plenty of time. Make Pittsburgh in two, maybe three hours.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Hey, he's right!  Whaddya say, Charlie, huh? Play a little pool? Wait out the heat?

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: About sixty, seventy bucks.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Next game, ten bucks.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Give me some bourbon. J. T. S. Brown.

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: You want a chaser?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Hey, another one for me and another one for the lady.

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: Check!

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You look different... More relaxed.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Give me a bottle of beer.

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: It's open...  What'll you have?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: You sure you going to be comfortable enough there, Miss... ah... ?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Packard. Sarah Packard.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: It always takes me a little while to get a name fixed in my mind. Are you sure you don't want anything?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: No, I'm fine.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: You, uh, you ever been to Louisville during Derby week, Miss, ah, Packard?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I've never been to Louisville.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Lots of action. Lots of money.  Lots of class. You'll see some of the best-dressed and most beautiful women in the world at the races. Knock your eye out.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I'm ready.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Soon as I finish my coffee.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: What makes you know so much? How do you know what Eddie was thinking?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: I know. Been there myself. We've all been there, haven't we, Miss Packard?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Doesn't your lighter work, Mr. Gordon?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Oh, I forgot all about it.  How's the hands?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: It's all right, Eddie. I'm sure Mr. Gordon meant no offense. It was a figure of speech.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: That's right, Miss Packard.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: And a fact is a fact.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: She's a smart girl, Eddie.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Oh, wait a minute, Miss Packard.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: We're neighbors now. You can call me Sarah.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: I want to talk to you.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Do we need words?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Yeah, I think we do. We could try to cut each other up. But that would be bad for everybody. Bad for me, bad for you. And worst of all, be bad for Eddie.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You know what's good for him?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: To win.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: For whom and for what?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: For what makes the world go round. For money, and for glory.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You didn't answer my first question. For whom?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: All right. Today for me, tomorrow for himself.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: No, there's no tomorrow. Not with you. You own all the tomorrows because you buy them today, and you buy cheap.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Well, nobody has to sell.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You bastard.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Listen, Miss Ladybird, you're here on a rain check and I know it. You're hanging on by your nails. You let that glory whistle blow loud and clear for Eddie and you're a wreck on a railroad track. You're a horse that finished last. So don't make trouble, Miss Ladybird. Live and let live. While you can.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: I'll make it up to you.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: You tell me.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Are you ready for another?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: In a little while. That's what you want, isn't it?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: It's what Eddie wants. He, uh, told me to give you some money.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Put it on the bed. That's the way it's done, isn't it?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: That's the way it's done.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: And the way you're looking at me, is that the way you look at a man you've just beaten? As if you'd just taken his money, and now all you want is... his pride?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: All I want's the money.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Sure, sure, just the money, and the aristocratic pleasure of seeing him fall apart. You're a Roman, Bert. You have to win them all.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Could be.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: Well, Mr. Felson, maybe you could come out to my place some evening. We could play a few games of billiards.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: We'll be there.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: Good, good.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: Oh, we'll start small... a hundred dollars a game.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: You ever played billiards before?

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: I'm sure Mr. Felson knows what he's doing. Certainly you can afford a hundred dollars to find out.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Deal the cards.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: How much?

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: Oh, about five hundred.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Do you really think you can beat him?

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: Of course he thinks he can beat me, Bert. He wouldn't be playing me if he didn't. Right, Felson?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: I didn't ask him can he beat you. I already know he can beat you. I asked him will he? With Eddie, that's two different things.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: Have you noticed, Bert? This fellow here bears a striking resemblance to you. It seems as though you might have modeled for the artist.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: It's possible.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: That seems a shame. The night is young.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: The night is two thousand dollars old.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: Will you take a check, Bert?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Cash.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: How much do I owe you?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Twelve thousand.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Hey, mister.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: The name's Gordon. Bert Gordon.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Mister. You been sittin' in that spot for hours. Would you mind moving? It bothers me.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Stay with this kid. He's a loser.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What did he say?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Okay?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Sit down.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Make it twenty.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Cut.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Deal.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Bourbon. J. T. S. Brown.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Two.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: I'm buyin'.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Thought you only drank milk.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Only when I work.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah? Why?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: I like it. It's good for you. Besides, you start drinking whisky gambling and it gives you an excuse for losing. That's something you don't need -- an excuse for losing. How did you make out in the poker game?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I lost twenty bucks.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Poker's not your game.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What is?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Pool.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You being cute?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: I don't think there's a pool player alive shoots better pool than I saw you shoot the other night at Ames. You got talent.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: So I got talent. So what beat me?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Character.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah. Sure, sure.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: You're damned right I'm sure. Everybody's got talent. I got talent. You think you can play big-money straight pool, or poker, for forty straight hours on nothing but talent? You think they call Minnesota Fats the best in the country just 'cause he's got talent? Nah. Minnesota Fats's got more character in one finger than you got in your whole skinny body.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I got drunk.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: He drank as much whisky as you did.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Maybe he knows how to drink.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: You bet he knows how.  You think that's a talent too, huh? Knowin' how to drink whisky? You think Minnesota Fats was born knowin' how to drink?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Okay, okay... What do I do now, lie down on the floor and, uh, bow from the ankles? What do I do, go home?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: That's your problem.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: So I stay. Stay until I hustle up enough to play Fats again. Maybe by that time I'll develop myself some character.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Maybe by that time you'll die of old age. How much do you think you'll, uh, need?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: A thousand.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: No, three thousand at least. He'll start you off at five hundred a game -- he'll beat the pants off you. That's the way he plays when he comes up against a man who knows the way the game is. He'll beat you flat four or five games -- maybe more, depending on how, uh... steady your nerves are. But he might -- he just might be a little scared of you, and that could change things. But I wouldn't count on it.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: How do you know? Huh? When nobody knows that much?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: See that big car parked out by the fireplug on the way in? Well, that's mine. I like that car. But I get a new one every year because I make it my business to know what guys like you and Minnesota Fats are gonna do. I made enough off of you the other night to pay for it twice over.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: In that case, you owe me another drink.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Eddie, is it all right if I get personal?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Whaddya been so far?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Eddie, you're a born loser.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What's that supposed to mean?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: First time in ten years I ever saw Minnesota Fats hooked, really hooked. But you let him off.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I told you. I got drunk.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Sure, you got drunk. That's the best excuse in the world for losing. No trouble losing when you got a good excuse. And winning! That can be heavy on your back too. Like a monkey. You drop that load too when you got an excuse. All you gotta do is learn to feel sorry for yourself. It's one of the best indoor sports: feeling sorry for yourself -- a sport enjoyed by all, especially the born losers.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Thanks for the drink.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Wait a minute. Maybe I can help you.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: To do what?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Get the three thousand. Play Minnesota Fats again.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Ten reasons. Maybe fifteen. And also there's something in it for me.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Oh yeah, I figured that. How much?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Seventy-five per cent.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: For who?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: For me.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: That's a -- that's a pretty big slice. Who do you think you are, General Motors?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: How much you think you're worth these days? I'm puttin' up the money, I'm puttin' up the time. For that I get seventy-five per cent return on my money -- if you win.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You think I can lose?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: I never saw you do anything else.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You saw me beat Minnesota Fats for eighteen thousand dollars.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Look, you wanna hustle pool, don't you? This game isn't like football. Nobody pays you for yardage. When you hustle you keep score real simple. The end of the game you count up your money. That's how you find out who's best. That's the only way.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Why back me then? Why not back yourself? Go find yourself a big fat poker game and get rich. You know all the angles.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: I'm already rich. But I like action. That's one thing I think you're good for is action. Besides, like I say... you got talent.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah, you already told me that. You cut that slice down to bite-size and maybe we can talk.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: No, we don't talk. I don't make bad bets. Seventy-five, twenty-five. That's it.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Kiss off.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Hey, wait.  What are you gonna do about the money?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: There are places. I'll scuffle around.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Word's out on you, Eddie. You walk in the wrong kind of place and they'll eat you alive.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Now, when did you adopt me?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: I don't know when it was.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Hello, Eddie.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Hi. How's business?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Ahh, slow... Why the open hand bridge? Something wrong with your hand?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah. Had a little accident. A place called Arthur's.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Oh. You seem to do all right that way.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I'd say my game is about twenty per cent off. Maybe more.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: What happened? Somebody step on your hands?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah. Big creep. Broke my thumbs.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Man named Turk Baker?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You know everybody, don't you?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Everybody who can hurt me, everybody who can help me. It pays.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Maybe you oughta give me lessons.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Sign up.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Where do I sign?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: The first match I got in mind for you is in Louisville, Kentucky.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You name the place, boss. I'll be there.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: What happened to you anyway?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Like I told ya. My thumbs.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: No, I don't mean the thumbs. You already told me about the thumbs.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I been thinking.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Thinking about what?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Maybe I'm not such a high-class piece of property right now. And a twenty- five per cent slice of something big is better than a hundred per cent slice of nothin'.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Hey, get us a couple of drinks here, will ya? J. T. S. Brown.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Sarah Packard... Bert Gordon.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Miss Packard. How do you do?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: James Findley is a very rich man. Grandfather left him twenty per cent of a tobacco company.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What? And he -- he hustles pool?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: He's a gentleman. Gentleman gambler. He gets his kicks playing with hustlers. He's got an old Southern mansion with a pool table in the basement, drinks eight-year-old bourbon, smokes cork-tipped cigarettes.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: How good is he?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: I don't know. Never saw him play. They say he's one of the best.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You must have a lot of confidence in me.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: I don't. But I got confidence in Findley.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What's that supposed to mean?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Means I got confidence that he's a loser. All the way a loser. You happen to be about only one-half loser -- the other half, winner.  I'm finished.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Here, I got it.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: No, no. When you play for me, I pick up all the tabs.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Fats knew the game was in the clutch, knew he had to do something to stop ya. He played it smart.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I played that game, Bert. In my head I played it a thousand times.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Play it again. Learn something.  Fats went in the john, see? Washed his face, cleaned his fingernails, made his mind a blank, combed his hair, came back all ready to go.  You were through. You saw him, you saw how he looked. Clean, all set to start all over again. Hold tight and push hard. You know what you were doing? You were waitin' to get beat. Flattened out on your butt, swimmin' around in glory. And whisky. Probably deciding how you could lose.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Good. I'd hate to think I was putting my money on a cripple.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Hey, whaddya say something like that for?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You know, that's real sweet music in there. You can almost smell the action and the money. You know, I can feel it right down in the bottom of my shoes.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Come on, let's go...

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Hey, Findley's here.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Over there by the bar.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Aren't you gonna go over and talk to him?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Nah. Sit tight. He'll be over here.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: So does Eddie.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Well, I win sometimes.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What's the matter? What happened?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: It's all right. She had a little too much to drink, that's all. Forget it.  Go upstairs and sleep it off.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Well, we won't.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: C'mon, Bert. Let me play him.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: How much?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: You hustlin' me?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: How do we stand?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: 'Bout even.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: When do I raise the bet?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Bert, if that's his best game, I can beat him.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Level with me, Eddie. You ever play billiards before?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What's the difference? You got a pool cue, balls on the table. All you gotta do is get the feel of it.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I can beat him.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: All right. Five hundred.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I'll beat him the next game.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: How're the hands?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: They're fine.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Well, rack up your cue. We're leavin'.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Hey, Bert. Wait a minute!

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: I said we're leavin'.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I can beat him, Bert. Now he suckered me 'cause he knows how to hustle. I didn't think he did. But I can outplay him. I can beat him.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: I don't believe you, Eddie. I think you're still a loser.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: All right, then. I'll play him with my own money.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Please don't get off me now.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: I know when to quit. You don't. Win or lose, you don't know when to quit.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What do you want me to do, huh? What do you want me to do? Just say it and you got it but PLEASE don't get off me now.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I wanna walk.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: It's a long walk.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I got time, Bert.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: You want me to tell her for you?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Tell her what?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: You gotta be hard, Eddie.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Eddie?...  YOU OWE ME MONEY!

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: And just how do you figure that, Bert? What do you figure I owe you?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Half.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: In Louisville it was seventy-five per cent.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Well, here it's half.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What if I don't pay ya, Bert?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: You don't pay me? You gonna get your thumbs broken.  And your fingers. And if I want them to, your right arm in three or four places.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: So you figure you're still my manager, huh?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: I'm a businessman, kid.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Well, you got a lot of games lined up for me?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Yeah, we're gonna make a lotta money together, from now on.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Fifty per cent?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: No, it don't have to be fifty. It can be thirty... twenty-five.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: We really stuck the knife in her, didn't we, Bert?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Aaaahhhh!

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Boy, we really gave it to her good.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: If it didn't happen in Louisville, it'd happened someplace else. If it didn't happen now, it'd happen six months from now. That's the kinda dame she was.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: And we twisted it, didn't we, Bert? Course, maybe that doesn't stick in your throat cause you spit it out just like you spit out everything else. But it sticks in mine. I loved her, Bert. I traded her in on a pool game. But that wouldn't mean anything to you. Because who did you ever care about? Just win, win, you said, win, that's the important thing. You don't know what winnin' is, Bert. You're a loser. 'Cause you're dead inside, and you can't live unless you make everything else dead around ya.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Maybe. You want to play?

turns.speaker: BIG JOHN
turns.text: No. Hell, no! You Eddie Felson?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Who's he?

turns.speaker: BIG JOHN
turns.text: What's your game? What do you shoot?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You name it, we shoot it.

turns.speaker: BIG JOHN
turns.text: Look, friend, I'm not trying to hustle. I don't never hustle people that walk into poolrooms with leather satchels. Don't try to hustle me.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Okay, I'm Eddie Felson. I shoot straight pool. You got any straight pool shooters in this here poolroom?

turns.speaker: BIG JOHN
turns.text: What kind of straight pool game you like?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: The expensive kind.

turns.speaker: BIG JOHN
turns.text: Come up here to play straight pool with Minnesota Fats?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah, that's right.

turns.speaker: BIG JOHN
turns.text: Want some free advice?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: He's my partner.

turns.speaker: BIG JOHN
turns.text: You well-heeled, partner?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You got that wrong, mister. I am.

turns.speaker: BIG JOHN
turns.text: Okay, I told you what I wanted about Minnesota Fats. You just go ahead and play him, friend.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Just tell me where I can find him, friend.

turns.speaker: BIG JOHN
turns.text: Comes right in this poolroom every night, eight o'clock on the nose. Just stay where you are. He'll find you.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Druggist supplies. Buster here is gonna get an award.  No, he sold seventeen thousand bucks' worth of stuff last month. Fastest boy in the territory.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yep. Fastest and the bestest... Hey, give us another round, will ya? One for him, one for yourself.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: It's gonna cost ya money. It always does.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Oh, come on, stop stalling. Grab yourself a cue.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You ought to take up crap shooting. Talk about luck!

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Luck! Whaddya mean, luck?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You know what I mean. You couldn't make that shot again in a million years.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I couldn't, huh? Okay. Go ahead. Set 'em up the way they were before.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Go ahead. Set 'em up the way they were before. Bet ya twenty bucks. Make that shot just the way I made it before.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Nobody can make that shot and you know it. Not even a lucky lush.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Set 'em up again... C'mon, set 'em up again.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You're drunk, boy. I'm not gonna bet ya any more.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Whaddya mean?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Let's get back on the road. You gotta be at that convention in the morning.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Up the flagpole with the convention. C'mon, Charlie. You're into me now. I got my money on the table.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I don't want it.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Well... well, now.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Don't be a chump. Don't bet any more money on that damn fool shot.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Well, now... I mean, you figure I'm a little drunk, and I'm loaded on the hip, and you just want in, real friendly, while the money's still floating, huh? Okay... Go ahead. Set 'em up.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: It's quiet.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah, like a church. Church of the Good Hustler.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Looks more like a morgue to me. Those pool tables are the slabs they lay the stiffs on.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I'll be alive when I get out, Charlie.
